1.brief: to see, literally or figuratively (in numerous applications, direct and implied, transitive, intransitive and causative)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
the Lord (used as a proper name of God only)
to station, in various applications (literally or figuratively)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
an altar
to say (used with great latitude)
to strike (lightly or severely, literally or figuratively)
a chaplet; but used only in an architectonic sense, i.e. the capital of acolumn, or a wreath-like button or disk on the candelabrum
to undulate (as the earth, the sky, etc.; also a field of grain), particularly through fear; specifically, to spring (as a locust)
a vestibule (as a limit); also a dish (for holding blood or wine)
figuratively, to finish, or (intransitively) stop
the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
the last or end, hence, the future; also posterity
drought; also a cutting instrument (from its destructive effect), as a knife, sword, or other sharp implement
to smite with deadly intent
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
to flit, i.e. vanish away (subside, escape; causatively, chase, impel, deliver)
to flit, i.e. vanish away (subside, escape; causatively, chase, impel, deliver)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles
properly, to be smooth, i.e. (by implication) to escape (as if by slipperiness); causatively, to release or rescue; specifically, to bring forth young, emit sparks
a refugee

2.brief: used very widely as demonstrative, lo!; interrogative, whether?; or conditional, if, although; also Oh that!, when; hence, as a negative, not
to force a passage, as by burglary; figuratively, with oars
Hades or the world of the dead (as if a subterranean retreat), including its accessories and inmates
there (transferring to time) then; often thither, or thence
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
used very widely as demonstrative, lo!; interrogative, whether?; or conditional, if, although; also Oh that!, when; hence, as a negative, not
to ascend, intransitively (be high) or actively (mount); used in a great variety of senses, primary and secondary, literal and figurative
the sky (as aloft; the dual perhaps alluding to the visible arch in which the clouds move, as well as to the higher ether where the celestial bodies revolve)
there (transferring to time) then; often thither, or thence

to descend (literally, to go downwards; or conventionally to a lower region, as the shore, a boundary, the enemy, etc.; or figuratively, to fall); causatively, to bring down (in all the above applications)

the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
Karmel, the name of a hill and of a town in Palestine
there (transferring to time) then; often thither, or thence
to seek; causatively, to conceal oneself (i.e. let be sought), or mask
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
used very widely as demonstrative, lo!; interrogative, whether?; or conditional, if, although; also Oh that!, when; hence, as a negative, not
to hide (by covering), literally or figuratively
a front, i.e. part opposite; specifically a counterpart, or mate; usually (adverbial, especially with preposition) over against or before
an eye (literally or figuratively); by analogy, a fountain (as the eye of the landscape)
floor (as if a pavement of pieces or tesseroe), of abuilding or the sea

a sea (as breaking in noisy surf) or large body of water; specifically (with the article), the Mediterranean Sea; sometimes a large river, or an artifical basin; locally, the west, or (rarely) the south
there (transferring to time) then; often thither, or thence
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)
to strike with a sting (as a serpent); figuratively, to oppress with interest on a loan

to walk (literally or figuratively); causatively, to carry (in various senses)
exiled; captured; as noun, exile (abstractly or concretely and collectively); by extension, booty

bad or (as noun) evil (natural or moral)
not (the simple or abs. negation); by implication, no; often used with other particles

good (as an adjective) in the widest sense; used likewise as a noun, both in the masculine and the feminine, the singular and the plural (good, a good or good thing, a good man or woman; the good, goods or good things, good men or women), also as an adverb (well)

a mass of persons (or figuratively, things), especially reg. organized forwar (an army); by implication, a campaign, literally or figuratively (specifically, hardship, worship)

properly, to touch, i.e. lay the hand upon (for any purpose; euphemistically, to lie with a woman); by implication, to reach (figuratively, to arrive, acquire); violently, to strike (punish, defeat, destroy, etc.)
the earth (at large, or partitively a land)
to melt, i.e. literally (to soften, flow down, disappear), or figuratively (to fear, faint)
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)

to ascend, intransitively (be high) or actively (mount); used in a great variety of senses, primary and secondary, literal and figurative
a channel, e.g. a fosse, canal, shaft; specifically the Nile, as the one river of Egypt, including its collateral trenches; also the Tigris, as the main river of Assyria

to subside; by implication, to be overflowed, cease; causatively, to abate, subdue
